Proper antenatal care is crucial for a healthy pregnancy. Key responsibilities include:
  • Ensuring the first check-up is within the first 12 weeks.
  • Motivating for a minimum of four ANC visits.
  • Distributing Iron Folic Acid (IFA) tablets and ensuring Tetanus Toxoid (TT) injections are administered.

Postnatal Care (PNC)
Care after delivery is vital for both mother and child. Your role is to:
  • Conduct the first home visit within 24 hours of delivery.
  • Perform at least 3-4 follow-up visits within the first 6 weeks.
  • Counsel on exclusive breastfeeding, nutrition, and how to identify danger signs in the mother and newborn.

Nutrition During Pregnancy
Advise pregnant women to consume a balanced diet rich in iron, calcium, and protein. Encourage intake of green leafy vegetables, dairy products, and lentils. Growth Monitoring
Regularly monitor the growth of children under 5. This includes:
  • Taking accurate weight and height measurements during home visits.
  • Plotting the measurements on the Growth Chart to track development.
  • Identifying signs of malnutrition (underweight, stunting) and counseling parents on appropriate feeding practices.

Nutrition for Infants and Children
Your counseling should focus on:
  • Promoting exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months.
  • Guiding the introduction of semi-solid complementary foods after 6 months, alongside continued breastfeeding.
  • Ensuring children receive their biannual Vitamin A supplementation as per the national schedule to prevent blindness and boost immunity.
The Importance of Vaccination
Vaccines are the most effective way to protect children from serious and life-threatening diseases like Polio, Measles, Tetanus, and Tuberculosis. Your role as a community mobilizer is to ensure every child completes their full immunization schedule on time.

Key Vaccines in the First Year:
  • BCG, OPV-0, Hep-B: Given at birth for protection against Tuberculosis, Polio, and Hepatitis B.
  • Pentavalent Vaccine: Protects against 5 major diseases (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B, and Hib). Given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks.
  • Rotavirus Vaccine: Protects against severe diarrhea. Given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks.
  • Measles/MR Vaccine: Given at 9 months to protect against Measles and Rubella, which can be fatal in infants.
Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK)
This scheme aims to reduce out-of-pocket expenses for pregnant women and sick newborns. Key entitlements include:
  • Absolutely free and no-expense delivery, including Caesarean section, in public health institutions.
  • Free transport from home to the institution, between facilities in case of referral, and drop back home.
  • Free care, drugs, and consumables for sick newborns up to one year of age.

Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY)
This is a maternity benefit program for pregnant women and lactating mothers for their first live birth. Key features include:
  • A cash incentive of ‚Çπ5,000 paid in three installments.
  • The objective is to provide partial wage compensation and ensure improved health and nutrition for the mother and child.
